subject: Re: [junit] chosing between jmock and easymock for mocks?
msgSnippet: Thanks for your reply, it cleared some things out for me and in some we just have different experiences, opinions and preferences, I guess.  ... Just to
messageBody:
Thanks for your reply, it cleared some things out for me and in some
we just have different experiences, opinions and preferences, I guess.

<snip>

> There is probably no one answer to that question. There is no question
> that EasyMock is, well, easier. (It's in the name after all.) But
> readability and refactorability of the code is not the only factor in
> determining which is better. I think you're forgotten that jMock has
> more features and flexibility than (at least) EasyMock 1.x. (I could be
> wrong, because I haven't touched EasyMock since early 2004.)

Just to clarify, I'm not using EasyMock, I'm using rMock the only
thing I can compare is a record/play framework to a declare framework
such as jMock.

I have not worked actively with EasyMock enough to have an opinion, I
have read the documentation and looked at the examples, in the 2.0
online documentation it is a bit more emphasized how to extend it but
if focuses mainly on the new 1.5 features, in the 2.0 documentation I
recognized more things from jMock in EasyMock but I don't know if they
have always been there and are just brought more to my attention now.
It is possible that I would like jMock more than EasyMock, i picked
jMock over EasyMock once upon a time espesially after reading the
jMock vs EasyMock comparison on the jMock site.

At the moment I am using and developing rMock 2.0. In terms of
flexibility and readability I have what I need there, some things are
more flexible than jMock some things are less flexible but imo it is
atleast as readable.

The featureset and clairity of rMock suits me but that is not a big
surprise since I participate in its development. I espesially like
that all tests tend to have the same structure in rMock (this is
driven by the fact that rMock allows _less_ flexibility in this area
than both Easymock and jMock).

One of the things I do value most with record/play frameworks is the
ability to ctrl+space your interfaces from your tests. The refactoring
part is not _as_ important once the interface has settled a bit but
still nice. I understand your point about the niceness of not having
to specify the methods before you have settled on them better after
your last mail, at least when you are extending existing interfaces
(that already have some implementations). I still prefer the ablity to
complete my methods it has become a natural way to wiork for me, in
this case i think it boils down to personal preferences.

All the best
/Joakim Ohlrogge
